newsitem.title: UK: IPE Brent steady, tests of resistance bounced.
newsitem.headline: IPE Brent steady, tests of resistance bounced.

text.p: IPE Brent crude futures tracked sideways on Thursday but trade was choppy as tests of resistance were bounced back leaving the market to trade just above unchanged, brokers said.
"We are stuck between a rock and a hard place at the moment and there's not enough volume in the buying or selling to push the market either way," a broker said.
At 1228 GMT July Brent was six cents up at $20.19 a barrel, struggling to brake resistance around $20.20 and with good support at just above $20.
June gas oil stood $2.25 firmer at $178.50 a tonne.
Despite the low volume some players were taking a more bullish stance.
Nicholas Wilson, analyst at MeesPierson said the target $20.50 remains intact even though the market has pulled back a little recently.
He saw good support in a band between $19.25 and $19.50 which represents a period of congestion on the July chart between May 12-15.
"Ultimately the next target is $20.20 with a further upside target at $21.35 and then taking out contract highs of $21.90," Wilson said.

He saw a similar pattern of trade for gas oil with the markets recent pull back having been very modest and its failure to fill a recent gap up and pull away from the highs and indication the market still has plenty of room to improve.

Reports that Turkish troops pushed deeper than ever into northern Iraq on Thursday, the ninth day of a drive against Kurdish separatist guerrillas which Baghdad has dismissed as a pointless pursuit of "ghosts", had little impact.
Iraqi Kurdish officials said Turkish troops had pushed 200 km (125 miles) into northern Iraq, a far deeper penetration of Iraqi territory than past incursions.
This follows Turkish reports that Iraq, Syria and Iran have all built up forces in the region.
The operation has been criticised by Turkey's Western allies and the United Nations.
